Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Summer Institute in Museum Anthropology at the Smithsonian Institution which provides an intensive four-week program to train graduate students to use museum objects in their research. Students will learn to collect data and analyze museum collections in light of anthropology's current research agendas, using a range of qualitative and quantitative methods and approaches. The training will take advantage of the Smithsonian Institution's vast anthropology collections and related resources, allowing students a hands-on experience working with museum specimens on individual projects. The Institute will focus on experiential learning, combining elements of a field school with classroom/laboratory training.

Anthropology collections at the Smithsonian and other museums represent an enormous national legacy, assembled over generations to document world cultures and serve anthropological research. However, many potential researchers are not effectively utilizing museum collections because they do not know how to approach or evaluate this type of data, which present distinct challenges. Few universities have the capacity to offer such training.

The Institute will train 36 graduate students over the three year course of the grant, leading to better research design and methodology in research on museum collections and an increase in theses and publications effectively utilizing museum objects. Through development and sharing of curriculum materials, it will serve as a model to encourage wider teaching of museum anthropology research methods and development of similar programs at university museums. The broader goal of the program is to use museums more effectively as sites for the production of knowledge. Increased productive use of collections will allow anthropology to capitalize on the investment made by former generations, as well as engage in research of interest and value to the communities where this material originated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Summer Institute in Museum Anthropology (SIMA) is to promote more effective use of museums as sites of knowledge production, allowing anthropology to capitalize on the investment made by former generations of collectors and to serve communities where material originated. It pursues that goal by teaching students to analyze museum collections in ways that address current research agendas in anthropology. The training is conducted in a four week residential program that makes intensive use of the collections of the Smithsonian’s Department of Anthropology. A further goal of the program, which was developed over the course of this grant, was to explore how the SIMA model of teaching and mentoring might be expanded not only to serve additional students but also university faculty, particularly at universities that have museum collections.

This was the sixth year of funding for SIMA and the final year of funding on this grant (see NSF Award BCS0852511 for details of previous grant). During the course of this funding cycle, SIMA provided training for an additional thirty-five (35) graduate students from twenty-five (25) universities. The cumulative total of students trained by SIMA over the full six years of the program is seventy-one (71) students from fifty-six (56) universities.

Guided by experience and formal feedback, we have arrived at a stable curriculum model that works well in support of our goals. It is a unique blend of lectures, one-on-one mentoring, and individual research projects, all utilizing Smithsonian collections. Lessons are focused on intensive training in understanding museum and archival systems, systematic data collection, and critical analysis. In addition, the curriculum explores the past and present connections between people and objects through readings and discussions and includes professional development sessions on ethics and on presenting research results. We require students to engage theory, but SIMA does not advance any particular theoretical paradigm. Instead, we work to help students establish methods to connect their theoretical positions to object data through direct experience. PI Candace Greene had primary responsibility for curriculum development and recruitment of visiting faculty to supplement resident Smithsonian faculty. Faculty were all committed to individual mentoring, and brought a wide range of perspectives and approaches to collections, demonstrating different research methods. In each year we included a few faculty from outside the U.S. in order to increase student awareness of international research trends.

In the final year of the grant, we began conversations with university colleagues about how the SIMA teaching model could be disseminated and emulated elsewhere. One outcome of this was the inclusion of “faculty fellowships” in our successful proposal to NSF (BCS1424029) for the continuation of SIMA through 2017. These fellowships will allow established faculty to observe SIMA activities while providing time for them to develop lesson plans and curricula suitable for their own university settings. In addition, Indiana University hosted a small workshop, led by Dr. Jason Jackson, to explore capacity building, there and elsewhere.
